abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated unsatisfactory since there was limited achievement of
            the project's main objectives. These lessons can be
            drawn: The project design should be adhered to to avoid the
            confusion that arises when project and non-project
            activities are planned and implemented differently.
            Technically unprepared components will lead to
            implementation difficulties, cost overruns, and delays. For
            components dependent upon the local communities for
            operations and maintenance, implementing agencies and the
            World Bank must ensure that decisions are discussed with and
            agreed upon by local stakeholders. Conditions set for
            project effectiveness should be indispensable to the
            project's implementation so as not to waste time. A
            review of expected cash flows of would-be veterinarian
            borrowers and of potential lending by commercial banks would
            have revealed up front that there was no basis for a credit
            component catering to private veterinarians. The frequency
            and skills mix of supervision missions should match project
            complexity. Quality supervision with components requiring
            specialized technical skills can only be assured through a
            team effort, and depends largely upon the task
            manager's experience. Recurrent expenditures need to be
            closely monitored. Using activities adopted by farmers as
            part of their normal practice helps sustain project components.
